c74object.name: bach.histo
c74object.description: Builds an histogram starting from a list of integer data (returning a list containing, for each position i, the number of appearances of the number i in the original data), or from a generic list of symbols and integers (returning unique symbols or numbers and their occurrences).

inlet.digest: The minimum integer value to be accounted for (or "auto")
The maximum integer value to be accounted for (or "auto")

objarg.name: mode
objarg.description: If you put sym as first argument, bach.histo will work in symbolic mode (see llll method).

objarg.name: minimum
objarg.digest: The minimum integer value to be accounted for (or "auto")
objarg.description: You can store the minimum value as first argument (see the atom method for more information).

objarg.name: maximum
objarg.digest: The maximum integer value to be accounted for (or "auto")
objarg.description: You can store the maximum value as first argument (see the atom method for more information).

method.name: atom
method.description:
This method only applies for default mode, not for symbolic mode. The histogram will contain in its i-th entry the number of appearences of number i in the original data. Yet the user can define a minimum and a maximum value of numbers i to be searched for: in this case the histogram will have an offset. For instance, if minimum is set to 4, the first entry of the histogram will contain the number of occurrences of 4, the second one the number of occurrences of 5, and in general the i-the entry will contain the number of occurrences of i+3.
Also, the number of entries of the histogram will correspond to the difference between the maximum and the minimum, plus one. One can of course leave minimum and maximum as "automatic" so that the first element of the histogram corresponds to the minimum value of the input llll, and the last element of the histogram corresponds to the maximum value of the input llll.
An integer in the first inlet sets a fixed minimum, an auto symbol links the minimum to the minimum value appearing in the original data llll.
An integer in the second inlet sets a fixed maximum, an auto symbol links the maximum to the maximum value appearing in the original data llll.

method.name: bang
method.description: Outputs the histogram of the most recently received reference number.

method.name: llll
method.digest: Set llll for analysis, output result
method.description: An llll in the first inlet sets the llll from which an histogram should be built. This list can either be a plain list, or any structured llll, in which case the analysis will work at the one-but-last level (thus on plain lists) and then will recollect the result in an llll containing all the histograms structured exactly according to the input llll shape. In default mode, the histogram will contain in its i-th entry the number of occurrences of number i in the original data (also reporting 0-occurrence elements); the llll with the i's is also output through the second outlet. In sym mode, the histogram will output appearing elements from second outlet and their occurrences from leftmost outlet, (never reporting 0-occurrence elements).

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the followings:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.

c74object.discussion: bach.histo also works for tree-structured lllls, by working on the lists at the one-but-last level of depth, and structuring the results according to the incoming llll.
